name: I am a Potato
comment info: In 2016 it stays at around 6% but in 1980 it goes to over 8% and then starts to drop.

name: PotatoesMakeMeHappy
comment info: I think birth control has increased over the years. I'm very surprised at the number decrease from 1980 and 2016. I never expected there to be so many differences.

name: Elizabeth
comment info: I think the descrepany shown in these graphs is due to multiple social factors. Since 1980, women have become much more career/education. I would be interested to see corresponding graphs from each year depicting the number of women enrolled in college or graduate school, as I believe an increase in education could be partially responsible for the changing ages of first-time mothers. I also think that financial status plays a significant role.

replies.comment info: @Elizabeth You have a very good statement, though I would also add birth control and adoption rates. I sincerely think these play a big part in this graph.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Elizabeth this would be a good idea to know of and research of.

name: lynn
comment info: I think that women began being more independent and wanted to focus on their careers. In 1980, it was normal for young women to just have children and stay home. In recent years, women stand up for themselves more and have their own opinions or goals. That is why I think that the graphs are so different.

name: Joe
comment info: I think that the increasing age of first-time motherhood is most likely due to societal and economic changes between 1980 and 2016. As many others have suggested, an increased societal acceptance of abortion and birth control would lead to women feeling more comfortable using these products, and so waiting longer to have a child. Additionally, as women gain more independence and freedom, they may decide to put college or their career over having a child at a young age, further pushing back the age of  first-time motherhood. Finally, as the cost of college and living has increased since 1980, young women in 2016 face more economic burdens than those in 1980, and aren't financially able to afford a child due to debt from student loans and overall have less money.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Joe and classmates --

You all mention that the age of first-time mothers has increased.  But, there are two peaks in the 2016 graph.  There are many 2016 mothers who are no older than the mothers in 1980.  I wonder why there are two peaks.  
Also, want to write a catchy headline that captures the main idea of these graphs and share them with us?

name: Jenn
comment info: A major difference that stood out to me when I analyzed these graphs was how older first time mothers increased from 1980 to 2016. Technology and medicine are increasingly intertwined as time goes on and there are many more alternate ways to have a child now than there were in 1980. Another important point is that many more women in this current time period attend college and spend most of their 20's trying to become stable in a career path than in the 1980's. College is a big expense and one that can not be payed off while simultaneously paying to raise a child. It is unrealistic to expect to be able to pay off college loans and have a child at the same time, because both are very costly. Something else that could be a reason for first time mothers becoming older is the fact that birth control and emergency contraceptives have become more accessible to women. 1980 is not many years after Roe v. Wade, so the concept of abortions and birth control was new, unknown, and not very accessible.

name: Anna
comment info: After observing the graphs, it is clear that the average age at which women would become first-time mothers in 1980 was around 20/21 years old. The average age in 2016 was much less clear as it is more even across ages ranging from 20-31. I believe that this is mainly due to increase in birth control which has given women the ability to decide when to start a family. Women are also now more career oriented causing them to start families later in life.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Anna--

How about a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea?

name: Katherine
comment info: After looking at the two graphs, we see the age of first time mothers shift toward the left of the graph, indicating a delay in the time women are starting their families. This could be attributed to many different things, including societal changes in the U.S. Women have become more independent and career driven, which has caused them to marry later and thus start families later as well. I also think that economic stability plays a role, and people will wait until they are well into their career to have children.

name: Mary
comment info: The average ages of first-time mothers have shifted towards  The attitudes towards birth control and abortion have changed drastically since 1980, even with extreme partisan opinions on organizations like Planned Parenthood. Accessibility of birth control has also brought a destigmatization of the use of  it, making safe sex more common. Additionally, women have been awarded more opportunities in the workforce, and women pursuing careers are likely to delay the starting of families.

name: Maggie
comment info: These two graphs seem to exemplify the social change that has occurred over the past 30 years. As many people have discussed, birth control and abortion have become much more normal in American society, whereas in the 1980s contraception was a newer part of society. Additionally, I think the shift in the graphs from 1980 to 2016 showcase many women's wish to start up a career. Finally, I am interested to see what the different colors mean, since there are multiple different shades of two colors.

name: Kevin
comment info: The graphs are a symptom of wide-sweeping social and medical reform. Gone are the days of the domestic sphere, where women were sidelined from industry to raise kids. Women were taught (including around the 1980s) a large portion of their self-worth and identity is based upon the quality of their family and their husband. With a new definition of their role in society (or lack thereof) women choose to start families later. This is even more unsurprising when considering the rise in women attending college. All in all, these graphs should be considered an indication of great social and cultural changes.

name: Tomasz
comment info: The change in the graphs between the two time periods could relate to marriage rates as well as the roles of women in society. More women might wait longer to get married and thus have kids when they are older than when they are in their 20's in 1980. Also, since more females have gone to pursue more work opportunities they have waited to have children as the costs of everyday life increase.

name: Cameron
comment info:
The 2016 first time mothers list has two peaks whereas the 1980 chart only has one major peak. People are having less children in their early twenties in 2016 than they were in 1980 and a larger group has emerged later in the early 30’s demographic where there wasn’t one before.
In terms of questions, why are their two almost identical rate of birth at different ages on the 2016 chart? Why is there a slight lull in birth rate between the early 20’s and 30’s? Is the main cause of this new developments in the understanding of fertilization? 
A good title for the article could be "More Women are Having Children Later in Life."

name: Luis Herrera
comment info:
Headline: The age to start your family.

I notice in the graphs that in 1980 it was more accepted to have a child at an early age like 20 rather than 40, but in 2016 it was accepted for women of all ages to have children. I wonder what societal changes caused the change at which women have children. I think that with time peoples ideas and views on certain topics may change.

name: Mackintosh Middle School Mathematicians
comment info:
After observing these graphs, we saw that instead of having a large skew toward the right like in 1980, there was a larger plateau between 20-30 in the 2016 graph. We would like to ask about what do the colors symbolize? What are the meanings of the different shades? We did notice that in between the 2016 graph, where the purple becomes the green , there lies a dip between the two peaks (modes). 
Headline: Ages of first-times mothers changing in last quarter of the century.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Mackintosh Middle School Mathematicians --

Though the designers of the graph may have used the colors for artistic reasons, I bet it has to do with the data. Observe the color for particular ages.  What do you notice?  Now, explain the effect of having bars vary by color.

name: MIGGYBOOM
comment info: After observing these graphs, I noticed that the distribution for 1980 is skewed right, with most women having their first child in their early twenties. In contrast, the graph for 2016 is more symmetric, with a wider range of ages for first-time mothers. There are a variety of possible explanations for this. Part of the discrepancy between the graphs may be due to changing attitudes on birth control between 1980 and 2016. More importantly, however, I think social changes are a significant factor; as women attend college and seek more jobs, they often spend more time building a life for themselves before ultimately settling down with a family.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @MIGGYBOOM i agree that birth control is way more effective now and women have more freedom to go to college and get a job

name: Ryan
comment info: I noticed on the second graph there are two modes. Also, inbetween the two modes there was a clear dip. Me and my pers thought that this was strange that a lot of women have kids at young ages, and at young old ages. We also thought that we whould you have a kid for the first time at 44 which is about the midddle of the avrage life.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Ryan --
Take a look at the other student responses. 
Why, in 2016, are there many first-time mothers who are around 29 years old.  Share with us  any ideas you have.

name: caroline
comment info: Societal changes from 1980 to 2016 has affected the quantity and age of first time mothers. The debate over reproductive rights has grown exponentially. Abortion and birth control pills have caused women to be in more control of when they want to be mothers. Also, the technology that is made available to women today is much more advanced than that in the 1980, therefore allowing women to be able to have children when they are older.

name: Matt
comment info: I think that the leading cause in the age of first time mothers getting older is the greater acception of abortion and birth control. In 1980, the country was less than a decade off the passing of Roe v. Wade, and because of this, many Americans were not yet comfortable with taking birth control medicine, or having an abortion. Now, in the 21st century, there is now more of acception of these birth control methods, which in turn leads to more women using it. With the rise of Planned Parenthood, and the support of many politicians throughout the country, abortion and birth control have led to a decrease in younger women becoming pregnant with a child.

name: Justin
comment info: After observing these graphs, I noticed that the distribution for 1980 is skewed right, with most women having their first child in their early twenties. In contrast, the graph for 2016 is more symmetric, with a wider range of ages for first-time mothers. There are a variety of possible explanations for this. Part of the discrepancy between the graphs may be due to changing attitudes on birth control between 1980 and 2016. More importantly, however, I think social changes are a significant factor; as women attend college and seek more jobs, they often spend more time building a life for themselves before ultimately settling down with a family.

name: Muro
comment info: I am looking forward to additional information being posted this afternoon.  I am hoping this information includes other graphs that might allow for an expansion of the conversation.  For instance, graphs indicating or comparing the number of 2 income households or women attending 4 year post secondary institutions for the same years as the original graphs.

name: Alex
comment info: I noticed several changes in the graphs. First, the range of ages that women are having children is more spread out in the second graph. In the first graph, the common age to have children was around 18-22, but in the second graph, there is less of a "common" age to have children. There isn't one age that stands out. I think there are several reasons as to why women are waiting to have children. They could be taking time to focus on their careers or education. Since birth control is more common now than it was in 1980, people are better able to plan when they want children. I think there are several factors causing the change in the graphs rather than one specific driving force.

name: Thanos
comment info: We noticed that the numbers start at a really early age and end very old for example, it starts at 14 and ends at 44. We also noticed that the percentages for the first time mothers had changed since 1980 to 2016. Women are having kids at later ages. I also noticed that the number peaked at the age 19 in 1980. I also say that the number peaked at the age 20 in 2016. I wonder what the colors on the graph means. I why the younger ages are pink and the older ages are green.The story these graphs are telling is first time mothers have decreased extremely since 1980.

name: Michael
comment info: We noticed that older women in 2016 were first-time mothers unlike in 1980. Also in 1980 the younger females were more first-time mothers than in 2016. "First Time Mothers Getting Older?"

replies.name: C
replies.comment info:
@Michael 
One reason that first time mothers tend to be older in 2016 than in 1980 could be because of an increase in the use of birth control and contraceptives since 1980. Additionally, a larger amount of women are joining the workforce and living independently before getting married. Since women are getting married later, they also tend to have children later.

name: Sarah
comment info: I noticed that in the 1980s, most of the mothers were 20-22 years old, while the mothers in 2016 ages varied and ranged in ages 20-30ish. replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Sarah A possible reason for this change in the ages of first-time mothers is that in 2016 more women get better educations and careers, delaying the time they have their first children. Better sex education in schools could also account to older first-time moms, as more younger people are using birth control thus not getting pregnant as early in their life as women in 1980.

replies.name: M

name: Sam
comment info: What I noticed for the 1980's graph is that there is a rapid incline between ages, and then once the ages increase, the percents decrease. The highest percent of women who are pregnant are of age yet under 25 years of age. Many of the women in the 80s are not having children at older ages as women in 2016 are.

name: Tucker
comment info: I noticed that more women are having babies at older ages now vs in the 1980s. In 1980s the highest age women were having babies at 19. I wonder if since society has been pushing women to wait to have kids until they are married is why rate for younger women has went down.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info:
@Tucker 
While you bring up a valid point, I believe your analysis to be a bit misconstrued. Perhaps rather than society pushing for women to have babies as they get older, women are opting to take career paths and furthering their education. Also since the 80's, the use of contraceptives and more access to abortions has made unplanned pregnancies and teen pregnancies much more uncommon.

name: Leigha
comment info:
What I noticed: 
More mothers were younger when they had children in 1980 than in 2016.

What I wonder:
Is it because younger people had more money back then?

What may be going on:
Inflation; younger people may not have as much money to take care of a child.

Title: Inflation = Less children?

name: norman anderson
comment info:
What I noticed

Women are having their first babies at an older age, fewer young mothers and more older mothers.  Instead of peaking at a specific age, many ages are near the peak which may suggest choice rather than fate.



What I wonder

Is this true for all areas of the country and is it different for different SES strata.  Also, the graph from 1980 was at the early period of increased birth control methods and in2016, many effective methods are available.  Are the differences in the graphs attributable to increased birth control.

What may be going on.

Societal changes secondary to technology and innovation.  Recent societal changes may also relate to increased electronic communication, economics and perceived changes in intimacy.

name: Peter
comment info:
There is a massive spike on the 1980 graph. There are percents.  It goes up by 2 percent. There are colors. 2016 graph is a lot more balanced. The 2016 graph shows less teens are having kids and more adults are having kids. I wonder why some many teens had kids as young as they were. What might be going on is that it shows that as the years progress, people are waiting to have children later in their lives. This could be an effect of how there are many medications and ways to block pregnancies. 

Title: Birth Rates In The Past Decades

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: The effect of the Roe vs. Wade (1973) court decision had not yet influenced society as it was less than a decade later than when this data of 1980 first time mothers was taken. Now, the use of birth control and healthcare, along with better sex education in public schooling, has allowed for women to plan the timing of having children much better. The higher age of women having their first child is higher due to these factors.

name: Moderator Justin
comment info:
Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  We’d love to see more catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph.  You can continue to post responses. Dig deeper into these histograms! Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, Nov. 29 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and two Stat Nuggets! 

The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, NOV. 29, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, DEC. 5!  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to What's Going On In This Graph?  

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who had her first child a decade later than her mother had her first child, and Justin Grieves from Charleston Southern University, who had two children so that trick-or-treating and trips to the toy store could continue a while longer!

comment info:

replies.comment info:
HI, @Lando9mitchell --
Teens “not using protection when they have sex” may be one reason for the 2016 shape with two peaks, one at about 21 and one at about 29.  So, why are there not two peaks in 1980?  What other reasons could there be for different shaped graphs?

name: Tfue
comment info: Why does the graph end at 8%

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Tfue It ends at 8% because no age has a higher number.

replies.name: j
replies.comment info: @Tfue the graph does this because the people that made it wanted it to.

Good morning, @Tfue –
That’s a great question.  
This is a histogram with the variable – age of first-time mothers on the x-axis.  The y-axis is the percentage of first-time mothers in each one-year interval.  For, example, in 1980, 4% of all first-time mothers were 16 years old.  
You may be asking why the maximum percentage is 8% for both the 1980 and 2016 graphs?  It makes it easier to compare graphs when they have the same axes  --  the same minimum, maximum, and interval widths for each of the axes.  Since the 1980 frequencies exceed 8%, the graph designers could have used 10% for both graphs, but maybe they had other reasons to use only 8%.

name: Cal
comment info: Why does the graph change colors.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Cal –
That’s a great question.  
You’d expect that the color change means something.  What do you hypothesize?  Maybe this will give more meaning to the graph.  Or, maybe it's just artistic.  
Does anyone else have an idea?

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Today’s histograms shows the age of American first-time mothers in 1980 and 2016.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  Plus, share with us a catchy headline. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these infographics and much more.
We look forward to reading your discoveries.

(The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, November 29 with moderation on Wednesday, December 5.)

name: Liana
comment info: I notice that the graph of 1980 is unimodal with the greatest % of first-time mothers at 19 years old with over 8%. The 2016 graph has data that is more evenly distributed. The greatest % of first-time mothers (6%) is at 20 years old but what's interesting is that 28 years old is close to 6% as well. I wonder why the age of first-time mothers has gotten older and why women now are having their first child in between a larger range of ages. My title would be "Why are mothers getting older?"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Liana.
You noticed that the distribution of the age of first-time mothers has changed between 1980 and 2016.  What do you think has caused this change?  Do you think it will stay this way or revert to the 1980 distribution?  What do you (or any other students) think will happen?

name: Lalan
comment info: I am not surprised by this graph either McBride.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lalan –
Why are you not surprised by the 2016 graph?  McBride responded that the bimodal (2-peaks) graph is not surprising because of the increased acceptance of birth control since 1980.  How does this result in a bimodal distribution?  Share with us any other reasons for the change in shape of the distribution between 1980 and 2016.  
Also, do you have a headline for us?

name: G. McBride
comment info:
I wasn't surprised by these graphs. With Roe v Wade in 1973 and the further acceptance of birth control, I wonder if this is why mothers have gotten older. I noticed the 1980 graph peaks at 19, while the 2016 graph has a rather flat "plateau" between the ages of 19 and 31. I also noticed that first-time mothers at any age make up less than 6 percent in 2016, but in 1980, women between 18 and 20 made up about 24 percent of all first-time mothers. I wonder if there is a correlation between more women in the workforce and overall increase in age of first-time mothers?

A good headline for this would be "First-time Mothers Getting Older in the New Millennium"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @G. McBride –
Nice headline:  "First-time Mothers Getting Older in the New Millennium."
You imply that first-time mothers may be older because of the acceptance of birth control.  May there be other reasons for older first-time mothers?  Do you think this trend will continue?

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: i do agree with not being surprised by the graphs and the information being shown in them. As well as agreeing to what is being noticed by the 2016 graph.@G. McBride

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @G. McBride I also was not surprised by the graph due to 1980's close proximity to Roe v. Wade in 1973. I definitely think birth control is part of the change in distribution, however, I also think part of this shift comes from an increased participation of women in the workforce and financial independence as you mentioned in your response. The 1980s still had a lot of "housewife" standards for women, and women continued to break out of the domestic sphere over the following 30 years. I think this increased participation in the workforce is what allowed women to live more independently, which is why the overal age of first time mothers has gone up, and why the overall birth rate has gone down.
